summary: The Grand Island Trail Run is a breathtaking ultramarathon held on a remote wilderness island in Michigan's Lake Superior, featuring a 50K course that circles the island's rugged perimeter. Runners encounter a stunning variety of terrain, from 300-foot sandstone cliffs and white sand beaches to dense old-growth hardwood forests with views of the Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore.
uniqueFeatures: Island Access Logistics: The race takes place on a non-motorized island reachable only by ferry, creating a secluded and immersive wilderness experience for a limited field of 500 runners.
Dramatic Coastal Views: Much of the course is perched atop 300-foot-high Jacobsville sandstone cliffs, offering participants constant, wide-angle views of the crystal-clear waters of Lake Superior.

Eco-Sustainable Design: As a cupless and eco-conscious event, the race mandates that runners carry their own hydration systems to protect the island's pristine ecosystem while navigating through its diverse inland and coastal trails.

media.title: A Marathon-Sized Island
media.summary: An editorial reflection on the unique experience of running the Grand Island Trail Marathon, highlighting the remote wilderness and the logistical charm of a ferry-access race.
media.contentSummary: Robert James Reese provides a personal race report of the Grand Island Trail Marathon in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. The narrative covers the logistical challenges of traveling with a toddler, the scenic yet demanding trail features like Lake Superior beaches and steep hills, and a notable encounter with a hornet's nest at mile six.
